stem: Identify the fetal heart rate (FHR) deceleration and its primary cause.
template: A FHR pattern characterized by a gradual decrease and return to baseline that mirrors the uterine contraction is a {{pattern1}}, while a sudden 'V' shaped drop that occurs at any time is a {{pattern2}} caused by cord compression.

rationale.correct: **Early Deceleration:** This deceleration mirrors the uterine contraction, with the nadir (lowest point) occurring at the peak of the contraction. This is typically a benign finding caused by fetal head compression, stimulating the vagal nerve and slowing the heart rate. No intervention is usually required. **Variable Deceleration:** This deceleration is characterized by a sudden, abrupt drop in FHR, often 'V' shaped, and can occur at any time in relation to the uterine contraction. The primary cause is umbilical cord compression, which reduces fetal oxygenation. Repositioning the mother is often the first intervention.
rationale.incorrect: **Late Deceleration:** This deceleration begins after the peak of the uterine contraction and recovers after the contraction ends. This indicates uteroplacental insufficiency, meaning the placenta is not delivering enough oxygen to the fetus. This is a concerning sign requiring immediate intervention. **Acceleration:** This is a visually apparent abrupt increase (onset to peak less than 30 seconds) in the FHR above the baseline rate. Accelerations are generally considered a sign of fetal well-being.
clinicalPearls: Remember VEAL CHOP: Variable-Cord compression; Early-Head compression; Acceleration-Okay; Late-Placental insufficiency.
Maternal position changes (e.g., left lateral) can often alleviate cord compression causing variable decelerations.
If late decelerations are present, interventions include administering oxygen (10 L/min via non-rebreather mask), increasing intravenous fluids, and notifying the healthcare provider.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Carefully assess the timing of the deceleration in relation to the uterine contraction. Early decelerations mirror the contraction, while late decelerations begin after the peak of the contraction.

mnemonic.title: VEAL CHOP
mnemonic.expansion: Variable decelerations - Cord compression; Early decelerations - Head compression; Accelerations - Okay; Late decelerations - Placental insufficiency

reviewUnits.heading: Fetal Heart Rate Monitoring
reviewUnits.body: Review the different types of FHR decelerations (early, late, variable) and their associated causes and interventions. Understand the significance of baseline FHR, variability, and accelerations.
